explanation:
The reported violation is not confirmed by the provided code. Rule 21.17 concerns actual uses of <string.h> functions that can read past object bounds. The function handle_recv_no_space itself does not call any <string.h> functions; it only forwards c->read_buffer and its valid length c->read_buffer_offset to helper functions (handle_req_headers_no_space, handle_req_chunk_size_line_no_space, handle_req_footers_no_space). Whether a Rule 21.17 violation exists depends entirely on the implementations of those callee functions. If any of those callees use string.h routines that expect NUL-terminated C strings (e.g. strlen, strchr, strchrnul, strspn, etc.) without ensuring a terminating NUL within the provided length, then that would indeed violate Rule 21.17. But no such misuse is visible in the shown fragment, so the claim that handle_recv_no_space itself violates Rule 21.17 is not correct as presented.

Recommendation: inspect the implementations of the callee functions. To be safe, either (a) ensure the buffer is NUL-terminated at or before read_buffer_offset before calling APIs that expect C strings, or (b) ensure the callees use length-aware operations (memchr/memmem/memcmp or bounded variants like strnlen with the known max) so they cannot read beyond the provided length.
